item.title: NETTLES IN IRISH COOKING: FROM SPRING SOUPS TO HERBAL REMEDIES
item.description:
Table of Contents Part 1: Introduction – Nettles in Irish Tradition Part 2: Harvesting and Preparing Nettles Safely Part 3: Classic Irish Nettle Recipes Part 4: Nettles as Herbal Remedies in Folk Medicine Part 5: Nettles in Modern Irish Cuisine and Sustainability Introduction – Nettles in Irish Tradition The humble stinging nettle (Urtica dioica) has long held a place of respect in Irish cooking and folk medicine. Far from being just an invasive weed, nettles were once an essential springtime food, valued for their nutritional richness and versatility in the kitchen. In fact, generations of Irish households knew that when the first tender nettles appeared in March and April, it marked not only the coming of warmer days but also the arrival of one of nature’s healthiest greens. A plant of necessity and resilience: Nettles were widely used across rural Ireland, particularly during the “hungry gap” of early spring when winter food stores were running low. Families would gather young nettle shoots from hedgerows and fields, boiling them into soups or teas that were both nourishing and restorative after the long, harsh winters. The plant’s ability to grow almost anywhere, from stony soils to damp meadows, made it a dependable resource for poor communities. Cultural and symbolic roles: Beyond the table, nettles carried symbolic significance in Irish culture. In some regions, nettles were believed to ward off evil spirits when hung above doorways. On “Bealtaine” (May Day), nettle stings were thought to protect health and ensure vitality for the summer ahead. Such beliefs intertwined practical use with spiritual tradition, highlighting how deeply embedded nettles were in daily life. Nutritional powerhouse: Modern science confirms what past generations seemed to know intuitively—nettles are packed with vitamins and minerals. Rich in iron, calcium, magnesium, and vitamin C, they were especially important in combating nutritional deficiencies common in rural Ireland. Their high chlorophyll content also made them a natural tonic for energy and blood health, something farmers and laborers greatly valued. A forgotten staple revived: While nettles gradually fell out of everyday Irish cooking with modernization and easier access to cultivated greens, they are now making a comeback. Contemporary chefs and foragers are once again celebrating the plant’s flavor—somewhere between spinach and cucumber—and its sustainable appeal as a free, abundant, and nutritious ingredient. From ancient folk remedies to today’s gourmet kitchens, nettles have never truly disappeared from Ireland’s food story.  Harvesting and Preparing Nettles Safely While nettles are highly nutritious and flavorful, their stinging hairs can make them intimidating to handle. For centuries, Irish households passed down practical knowledge on how to gather and prepare nettles safely, turning a prickly plant into a beloved spring ingredient. Understanding the right techniques ensures that nettles can be enjoyed without discomfort. When to harvest: Nettles are at their best in early spring, typically from March to May, when the young shoots are tender and packed with nutrients. Once the plant matures and begins to flower, the leaves develop a coarse texture and can become bitter. Traditionally, Irish foragers would only pick nettles before June, knowing that young leaves made the most delicious soups and teas. How to pick nettles: The golden rule of nettle harvesting is to wear gloves. Thick gardening gloves or even simple cloth gloves prevent stings from the tiny, hair-like needles on the stems and leaves. Using scissors or shears, snip the top 4–6 inches of the plant, as these younger tips are softer and less fibrous. Always harvest away from roadsides or polluted areas to ensure the leaves are clean and safe to eat. Neutralizing the sting: Fortunately, nettle stings disappear as soon as the plant is cooked or dried. Boiling, steaming, or sautéing nettles for just a few minutes completely removes the sting, leaving a tender, spinach-like green behind. Drying nettle leaves for tea also makes them harmless to touch and consume. Washing and cleaning: Like any foraged green, nettles should be thoroughly rinsed in cold water to remove dirt and insects. Some cooks recommend blanching the leaves briefly before using them in soups or recipes, both to soften them and to give them a vibrant green color. Storing nettles: Fresh nettles are best used immediately after harvesting, but they can be kept in the refrigerator for a day or two if wrapped in a damp cloth. For long-term use, many Irish households would dry the leaves for teas or freeze blanched nettles to preserve their nutritional value year-round. Harvesting nettles may require care, but once prepared, they are no more difficult to cook with than any leafy green. .  Classic Irish Nettle Recipes For generations, nettles have found their way into the Irish kitchen in simple but deeply nourishing dishes. Often considered a “poor man’s food,” nettles were both affordable and abundant, making them an essential ingredient during the lean months of spring. Today, these recipes are enjoying a revival as chefs and home cooks rediscover their earthy flavor and nutritional value. Nettle Soup: Perhaps the most iconic use of nettles in Ireland is the humble nettle soup. Traditionally, families boiled fresh nettle leaves with potatoes, onions, and leeks, creating a thick and warming dish to combat the chill of spring. Butter and cream were sometimes added when available, but even in its simplest form, nettle soup was hearty and restorative. Modern variations often blend the soup for a smooth texture and may include herbs like parsley or thyme for added flavor. (View Our Recipe) Nettle Colcannon: Colcannon, the classic Irish dish of mashed potatoes with greens, was occasionally made with nettles in place of cabbage or kale. Blanched nettles added a slightly nutty, spinach-like flavor, while also boosting the nutritional content. Served with butter melting in the center, nettle colcannon was a comfort food that combined practicality with tradition. Nettle Bread and Scones: Nettles were sometimes dried, ground, and mixed into flour to make rustic breads or scones. This practice not only stretched scarce flour supplies but also infused the bread with a rich green color and earthy flavor.

The post NETTLES IN IRISH COOKING: FROM SPRING SOUPS TO HERBAL REMEDIES appeared first on Irish Food Hub.

item.title: IRISH WHISKEY APPLE GALETTE
item.description:
Irish Whiskey Apple Galette – A Rustic Apple Tart with a Spirited Twist Irish Whiskey Apple Galette is a rustic tart that combines tender, flaky pastry with a rich apple filling enhanced by a splash of Irish whiskey. Simple yet elegant, this free-form dessert is the perfect way to enjoy Ireland’s orchard fruit traditions with a spirited twist. Best served warm with a dollop of cream or vanilla ice cream, it’s a comforting dessert with authentic Irish charm. Recipe Details Preparation Time: 20 minutes Cooking Time: 40 minutes Serving Size: Serves 6 Ingredients For the Pastry: 200g plain flour 100g unsalted butter, chilled and cubed 1 tbsp sugar Pinch of salt 4–5 tbsp cold water For the Filling: 4 medium apples, peeled, cored, and thinly sliced 3 tbsp Irish whiskey 3 tbsp brown sugar 1 tsp ground cinnamon ½ tsp nutmeg 1 tbsp plain flour For Finishing: 1 egg, beaten (for brushing) 1 tbsp sugar, for sprinkling Instructions Make the Pastry: In a bowl, mix flour, sugar, and salt. Rub in butter until it resembles breadcrumbs. Add cold water gradually until the dough comes together. Wrap in cling film and chill for 30 minutes. Prepare the Filling: In a bowl, toss sliced apples with Irish whiskey, brown sugar, cinnamon, nutmeg, and flour. Let sit for 10 minutes to soak. Assemble the Galette: Roll pastry into a rough circle on a floured surface. Transfer to a lined baking tray. Pile apples in the center, leaving a 5cm border. Fold pastry edges over the filling in rustic pleats. Bake: Brush pastry with beaten egg, sprinkle with sugar, and bake at 190°C (375°F) for 35–40 minutes until golden brown. Serve: Allow to cool slightly before serving warm with cream or vanilla ice cream. Why You’ll Love This Recipe The Irish Whiskey Apple Galette is rustic baking at its best – no fuss, no fancy pans, just flaky pastry and a boozy apple filling. The whiskey adds warmth and depth to the apples, making this tart a dessert that feels both homely and special. Perfect for sharing with friends or enjoying on a cozy evening.

The post IRISH WHISKEY APPLE GALETTE appeared first on Irish Food Hub.

item.title: IRISH PORTER CUPCAKES
item.description:
Irish Porter Cupcakes – Rich Stout Cakes with Chocolate Frosting Irish Porter Cupcakes are a decadent treat that blends the deep, malty flavors of Irish stout with the sweetness of chocolate. These small, moist cakes are baked with porter or stout for a rich depth of flavor and topped with smooth chocolate frosting for the perfect finishing touch. Ideal for parties, holidays, or simply indulging in a little Irish sweetness, these cupcakes are a crowd-pleasing dessert with a hint of tradition. Recipe Details Preparation Time: 15 minutes Cooking Time: 25 minutes Serving Size: Makes 12 cupcakes Ingredients For the Cupcakes: 200ml Irish porter or stout (such as Guinness) 100g unsalted butter 200g soft brown sugar 125g plain flour 50g cocoa powder 1 tsp baking soda 1 egg 100ml sour cream For the Chocolate Frosting: 150g dark chocolate 100g unsalted butter 150g icing sugar 2 tbsp milk Instructions Preheat Oven: Set oven to 180°C (350°F) and line a muffin tin with 12 paper cases. Make the Batter: In a saucepan, heat the porter and butter until melted. Stir in sugar, then whisk in flour, cocoa, and baking soda. Add the egg and sour cream, mixing until smooth. Bake: Divide the batter evenly among the cupcake cases. Bake for 20–25 minutes, or until a skewer inserted comes out clean. Cool completely. Prepare the Frosting: Melt the chocolate and butter together. Whisk in icing sugar and milk until smooth and creamy. Frost: Spread or pipe the frosting onto the cooled cupcakes. Why You’ll Love This Recipe These Irish Porter Cupcakes are moist, rich, and indulgent with just the right balance of sweetness and malty stout flavor. The chocolate frosting adds a silky finish, making them an irresistible dessert for any occasion, especially St. Patrick’s Day or Irish-themed gatherings.

The post IRISH PORTER CUPCAKES appeared first on Irish Food Hub.

item.title: THE FOOD HERITAGE OF THE ARAN ISLANDS
item.description:
The Aran Islands, a windswept trio of rocky outcrops off the coast of County Galway, are best known for their rugged beauty, distinctive culture, and enduring traditions. Yet one of the most fascinating aspects of island life is its food heritage—shaped by the Atlantic Ocean, the harsh limestone landscape, and the resilience of its people. From simple seafood dishes to unique farming practices, the Aran Islands offer a rich culinary story that reflects both hardship and creativity.  Table of Contents Living from the Land and Sea: Survival and Ingenuity Traditional Farming Practices on the Aran Islands Seafood Traditions: Harvesting the Atlantic’s Bounty Bread, Dairy, and Daily Meals in Island Life Preserving the Past: Food, Culture, and Tourism Today Living from the Land and Sea – Survival and Ingenuity The Aran Islands—Inis Mór, Inis Meáin, and Inis Oírr—have long been viewed as places of resilience. With little fertile soil and constant exposure to Atlantic storms, survival required ingenuity and resourcefulness. This reality is reflected in the islands’ food heritage, which emphasizes practicality, sustainability, and making the most of what the land and sea could provide. Creating soil from stone: One of the most remarkable aspects of Aran Island food history is the way locals created arable land. With no natural topsoil, islanders built their own by layering sand, seaweed, and manure between the cracks of the limestone. This labor-intensive process allowed them to grow potatoes, oats, and vegetables—crops that became dietary staples. The reliance on seaweed not only fertilized the land but also symbolized the deep connection between the ocean and daily survival. Fishing as a lifeline: The Atlantic Ocean was the other great provider. Fishing was essential, with mackerel, herring, and pollock forming the backbone of the island diet. Islanders often fished in currachs—lightweight, tar-covered boats that could withstand the Atlantic swells. Fish were eaten fresh when possible but were more often salted, dried, or smoked to ensure a supply through lean months. Foraging and self-sufficiency: Beyond farming and fishing, island families supplemented their diet with foraging. Seaweed varieties like carrageen moss and dulse were gathered for food and medicine. Wild herbs and berries were used to flavor meals or brewed into simple remedies. This culture of foraging reflected a holistic approach to food, where nothing in the environment was overlooked. Resilience through simplicity: The diet of the Aran Islands was never about luxury but about nourishment and endurance. Meals were plain but hearty—fish stews, boiled potatoes, porridge, and homemade bread sustained generations. The simplicity of the food mirrored the lifestyle: practical, communal, and deeply tied to the rhythms of the land and sea. The Aran Islands’ ability to create food traditions from such a challenging environment is a story of resilience and adaptability.  Traditional Farming Practices on the Aran Islands Farming on the Aran Islands has always been an extraordinary feat of determination and ingenuity. Unlike the fertile fields of mainland Ireland, the Aran landscape is dominated by bare limestone, with little natural soil. Yet over centuries, islanders developed farming techniques that transformed the seemingly barren rock into productive land capable of sustaining crops and livestock. Making soil from seaweed and sand: The most famous farming method on the Aran Islands was the creation of artificial soil. Islanders collected seaweed—especially kelp and wrack—from the shoreline and mixed it with sand carried from nearby beaches. Layer by layer, this mixture was spread into crevices and walled plots, gradually building up arable patches where crops could grow. This laborious process not only provided nutrition for plants but also symbolized the islanders’ reliance on the sea for survival. Stone walls as protection: The iconic dry-stone walls of the Aran Islands served more than just aesthetic or boundary purposes—they were essential for agriculture. The walls acted as windbreaks against Atlantic gales, preventing crops from being destroyed by harsh weather. They also helped retain the precious man-made soil within small plots, known as “clocháns.” These stone patterns still define the island landscape today, a testament to centuries of agricultural resilience. Crop staples: Potatoes were the primary crop, thriving even in the shallow soils the islanders created. Alongside them, oats and barley were commonly grown, providing porridge, bread, and fodder for animals. Vegetables such as cabbage, carrots, and turnips were also cultivated when possible, giving variety to otherwise limited diets. The small scale of farming meant that every inch of workable land was valued and carefully tended. Livestock and dairy: Despite the limited land, islanders also kept animals such as cows, pigs, and chickens. Cattle were particularly important, providing milk, butter, and cheese. Goats were also common on the islands, valued for their hardiness and ability to thrive on sparse vegetation. Livestock not only provided protein but also manure, which was essential for enriching the soil. Farming as community effort: Farming on the Aran Islands was rarely an individual task. Families and neighbors worked together to harvest seaweed, repair walls, and share resources. Seasonal rhythms dictated the agricultural calendar, with planting, harvesting, and seaweed collection becoming communal activities that reinforced social bonds. These farming practices demonstrate the deep relationship between the Aran people and their environment. By blending stone, seaweed, sand, and communal effort, they managed to carve out a living from an unforgiving landscape Seafood Traditions – Harvesting the Atlantic’s Bounty If the land of the Aran Islands demanded ingenuity, the surrounding Atlantic Ocean offered abundance. For centuries, fishing and seafood harvesting formed the backbone of the islands’ diet and economy. The sea not only provided food but also shaped the cultural identity of the Aran people, binding them to the tides, currents, and weather of the Atlantic world. Currach fishing: The currach, a lightweight, tar-covered wooden boat, became the essential vessel of Aran fishermen. Its flexible design allowed it to ride the Atlantic swells while still being light enough to carry ashore. Islanders used currachs to fish for mackerel, herring, pollock, and wrasse—species that thrived in the rich waters around the islands. Fishing was often a communal endeavor, with families sharing catches

The post THE FOOD HERITAGE OF THE ARAN ISLANDS appeared first on Irish Food Hub.

item.title: BACON RIBS WITH PARSLEY SAUCE
item.description:
Bacon Ribs with Parsley Sauce – A Rustic Dublin Classic Bacon Ribs with Parsley Sauce is a traditional Dublin dish that showcases Ireland’s love of hearty, rustic flavors. Made with salted pork ribs simmered until tender and served with a creamy parsley sauce, this comforting meal is a true taste of old Dublin cooking. Often enjoyed with mashed potatoes and cabbage, it’s a simple dish that has stood the test of time. Recipe Details Preparation Time: 10 minutes Cooking Time: 1 hour 30 minutes Serving Size: Serves 4 Ingredients For the Bacon Ribs: 1.5kg salted pork ribs 1 onion, halved 2 carrots, roughly chopped 2 bay leaves Black peppercorns, for seasoning For the Parsley Sauce: 50g butter 50g plain flour 500ml milk 1 large bunch fresh parsley, finely chopped Salt and black pepper, to taste Instructions Cook the Bacon Ribs: Place the salted pork ribs in a large pot and cover with cold water. Bring to the boil, then discard the water to remove excess salt. Refill the pot with fresh water, add the onion, carrots, bay leaves, and peppercorns. Simmer gently for 1–1.5 hours until the ribs are tender. Make the Parsley Sauce: In a saucepan, melt the butter, stir in the flour, and cook for 1 minute. Gradually whisk in the milk to make a smooth sauce. Simmer until slightly thickened, then stir in the chopped parsley. Season to taste. Serve: Arrange the bacon ribs on a serving platter and spoon the parsley sauce over the top, or serve on the side. Best enjoyed with mashed potatoes and boiled cabbage. Why You’ll Love This Recipe This dish is a piece of Dublin’s culinary heritage. The tender, salty pork ribs paired with the creamy freshness of parsley sauce make for a satisfying and comforting meal. Bacon Ribs with Parsley Sauce is rustic, traditional, and full of authentic Irish flavor – a true taste of Dublin’s past and present.

The post BACON RIBS WITH PARSLEY SAUCE appeared first on Irish Food Hub.

item.title: CODDLED EGGS WITH CREAM & HERBS
item.description:
Coddled Eggs with Cream & Herbs – A Simple Irish Comfort Dish Coddled Eggs with Cream & Herbs is a classic Irish-inspired dish that’s both comforting and elegant. Gently baked in ramekins, the eggs are enriched with cream and delicately flavored with fresh chives and parsley. Perfect for breakfast, brunch, or even a light supper, this dish is simple to prepare yet feels indulgent, especially when served with toasted brown bread for dipping. Recipe Details Preparation Time: 5 minutes Cooking Time: 12–15 minutes Serving Size: Serves 2 Ingredients 4 fresh eggs 4 tbsp heavy cream 1 tbsp fresh chives, finely chopped 1 tbsp fresh parsley, finely chopped Salt and black pepper, to taste Butter, for greasing Brown bread or toast, to serve Instructions Preheat your oven to 180°C (350°F). Lightly butter two ramekins or small ovenproof dishes. Crack two eggs into each ramekin and drizzle with 2 tablespoons of cream. Sprinkle with chopped chives and parsley, then season with salt and black pepper. Place the ramekins in a baking dish and pour hot water into the dish until it reaches halfway up the ramekins. Bake for 12–15 minutes, or until the whites are set but the yolks remain soft. Serve immediately with slices of toasted brown bread for dipping. Why You’ll Love This Recipe Light, creamy, and full of flavor, Coddled Eggs with Cream & Herbs is the perfect balance of rustic simplicity and refined taste. It’s a versatile recipe that can be enjoyed for a lazy weekend breakfast or a comforting evening meal, bringing a touch of Irish homeliness to your table.

The post CODDLED EGGS WITH CREAM & HERBS appeared first on Irish Food Hub.

item.title: THE RISE OF IRISH CRAFT CHOCOLATE: BEAN-TO-BAR IN THE EMERALD ISLE
item.description:
Chocolate may not be native to Ireland, but in recent years the Emerald Isle has carved out a name for itself in the world of artisanal bean-to-bar chocolate. A new generation of Irish chocolatiers is blending craftsmanship, sustainability, and a deep respect for Irish food heritage to create world-class chocolate with a distinctly Irish twist. From small coastal towns to bustling cities, craft chocolate makers are redefining how chocolate is made and enjoyed, transforming it from a sweet indulgence into a cultural experience.  Table of Contents The Origins of Craft Chocolate in Ireland Bean-to-Bar: What Makes Irish Craft Chocolate Unique? Meet the Makers: Ireland’s Leading Craft Chocolatiers Sustainability and Ethics in Irish Chocolate Making The Future of Irish Craft Chocolate: Trends and Global Recognition The Origins of Craft Chocolate in Ireland While Ireland has long been associated with rich dairy, hearty breads, and traditional sweets, chocolate has a surprisingly short but fascinating history on the island. For much of the 19th and early 20th centuries, chocolate in Ireland was dominated by imported brands and mass-produced confectionery. However, the seeds of a craft chocolate movement were planted in the late 20th century as Irish food culture began to embrace artisanal traditions, from farmhouse cheeses to craft beers. The early pioneers of Irish chocolate making often drew inspiration from European chocolatiers, particularly those in Belgium, Switzerland, and France. Small-scale producers began experimenting with higher-quality cocoa, using Ireland’s renowned dairy products—especially cream and butter—to create smooth, rich chocolates that reflected Irish culinary character. These early efforts were less about bean-to-bar production and more about crafting a premium product that went beyond the mass-market chocolate bars found in every shop. As Ireland’s food culture grew more sophisticated, with the rise of farmers’ markets, artisan bakeries, and a strong farm-to-table ethos, chocolate makers also began looking for ways to distinguish their craft. By the early 2000s, the global bean-to-bar movement was gaining momentum, with chocolatiers around the world sourcing cacao directly from farmers, roasting beans themselves, and controlling the entire chocolate-making process. Ireland, never one to shy away from blending tradition with innovation, soon found itself at the forefront of this shift. Coastal towns such as Dingle and small communities in Cork and Wicklow became unlikely hubs for chocolate experimentation. Here, independent chocolatiers began roasting cacao beans themselves, hand-tempering chocolate, and infusing their creations with local flavors—such as Irish sea salt, whiskey, honey, and even seaweed. These bold experiments not only put Irish craft chocolate on the map but also tapped into a growing demand for authenticity, sustainability, and unique taste experiences. In this way, Irish craft chocolate has mirrored the broader Irish food renaissance: rooted in tradition, inspired by the land and sea, yet open to global influences.  Bean-to-Bar – What Makes Irish Craft Chocolate Unique? The phrase “bean-to-bar” describes a chocolate-making process in which artisans oversee every stage of production—from sourcing raw cacao beans to creating the finished chocolate bar. Unlike mass-market producers, who often buy pre-processed cocoa liquor or couverture, bean-to-bar chocolatiers control each step, ensuring transparency, quality, and creativity. In Ireland, this approach has taken on a distinctly local character, shaped by the island’s culinary traditions and values. Direct relationships with cacao farmers: Irish craft chocolatiers emphasize ethical sourcing. Many work directly with small-scale cacao farmers in Latin America, Africa, and Asia, paying fair prices that support sustainable livelihoods. This farmer-focused approach echoes Ireland’s own history of small farming communities, fostering a sense of solidarity across continents. Roasting and flavor development: By roasting cacao beans themselves, Irish chocolatiers can experiment with temperature and time to highlight unique flavor notes. Just as Irish whiskey makers carefully distill to capture depth of flavor, bean-to-bar chocolatiers bring out profiles ranging from fruity and floral to nutty and earthy. The result is chocolate with a complexity rarely found in mass-produced brands. Irish terroir and local ingredients: What truly distinguishes Irish craft chocolate is the way it blends global cacao with Irish flavors. Makers often incorporate local ingredients such as sea salt from West Cork, honey from rural beekeepers, or whiskey from historic distilleries. Some even experiment with seaweed or wild herbs, tying chocolate to the Irish landscape in surprising ways. This fusion not only creates unique taste experiences but also grounds Irish chocolate in a sense of place.. Transparency and education: Many bean-to-bar chocolatiers in Ireland open their workshops to the public, offer tasting sessions, and educate consumers about the journey of chocolate. This emphasis on storytelling reflects Ireland’s cultural love of narrative, turning each chocolate bar into both a treat and a lesson about sustainability, farming, and craftsmanship. Small scale, big impact: While the number of Irish bean-to-bar producers is still relatively small, their impact is growing. Their focus on quality over quantity allows them to innovate with flavor combinations and production methods, positioning Irish chocolate as a premium product on the global stage. In short, Irish bean-to-bar chocolate is unique because it marries global connections with local identity. It takes the universal language of chocolate and gives it an Irish accent—one that speaks of authenticity, sustainability, and flavor. Meet the Makers – Ireland’s Leading Craft Chocolatiers The rise of Irish craft chocolate has been fueled by passionate chocolatiers who combine artistry, sustainability, and a deep respect for flavor. These makers, often working in small workshops along the coast or in rural towns, are redefining what Irish chocolate can be. Their dedication has placed Ireland firmly on the map of the global bean-to-bar movement. Bean and Goose (County Wexford): Founded by sisters Karen and Natalie Keane, Bean and Goose is one of Ireland’s most celebrated bean-to-bar producers. Their chocolate emphasizes seasonality and Irish terroir, often infused with ingredients such as hazelnuts, foraged berries, and sea salt from the Atlantic. They are also known for their beautifully designed bars that celebrate Ireland’s landscapes and traditions. Exploding Tree (County Cork): A pioneering bean-to-bar maker, Exploding Tree produces organic chocolate from ethically sourced beans. Their focus is on transparency and sustainability, and their flavors range from

The post THE RISE OF IRISH CRAFT CHOCOLATE: BEAN-TO-BAR IN THE EMERALD ISLE appeared first on Irish Food Hub.

item.title: IRISH CRAB CLAWS IN GARLIC BUTTER
item.description:
Irish Crab Claws in Garlic Butter – A West Coast Seafood Delight Irish Crab Claws in Garlic Butter are a true delicacy from Ireland’s Atlantic coast. Sweet and tender crab claws are gently cooked in rich garlic butter, creating a simple yet luxurious dish. Served with crusty bread to soak up every drop of the buttery sauce, this recipe is a seafood lover’s dream and a staple in many Irish coastal restaurants. Recipe Details Preparation Time: 10 minutes Cooking Time: 10 minutes Serving Size: Serves 2 Ingredients 400g fresh Irish crab claws, cleaned 3 tbsp unsalted butter 3 garlic cloves, finely chopped Juice of ½ lemon 1 tbsp fresh parsley, chopped Salt and black pepper, to taste Crusty bread, for serving Instructions In a large pan, melt the butter over medium heat. Add the garlic and cook gently for 1–2 minutes until fragrant but not browned. Add the crab claws and toss in the garlic butter for 4–5 minutes until heated through and coated. Squeeze in the lemon juice, season with salt and pepper, and sprinkle with chopped parsley. Serve immediately with warm crusty bread for dipping into the garlic butter sauce. Why You’ll Love This Recipe This dish captures the essence of Ireland’s coastal cuisine. Quick to prepare yet bursting with flavor, Irish Crab Claws in Garlic Butter are perfect as an appetizer, light meal, or indulgent seafood treat. The combination of tender crab meat, golden garlic butter, and fresh bread makes every bite unforgettable.

The post IRISH CRAB CLAWS IN GARLIC BUTTER appeared first on Irish Food Hub.

item.title: BOXTY PANCAKE WRAPS WITH BEEF AND ONION GRAVY
item.description:
Boxty Pancake Wraps with Beef & Onion Gravy – A Hearty Irish Classic Boxty Pancake Wraps with Beef & Onion Gravy bring together two Irish favorites: thin, tender potato pancakes and slow-cooked, melt-in-your-mouth beef. Rolled into a comforting wrap and drizzled with rich onion gravy, this dish is rustic, hearty, and deeply rooted in Irish tradition. Perfect for dinner or as a filling weekend treat, these wraps are a modern twist on the beloved boxty. Recipe Details Preparation Time: 20 minutes Cooking Time: 2 hours Serving Size: Serves 4 Ingredients For the Boxty Pancakes: 250g raw potato, finely grated 250g mashed potato 120g plain flour 200ml milk 1 egg Salt and black pepper, to taste Butter or oil, for frying For the Beef & Onion Gravy: 500g stewing beef, diced 2 onions, thinly sliced 2 tbsp plain flour 500ml beef stock 2 tbsp vegetable oil 1 tbsp Worcestershire sauce Salt and black pepper, to taste Instructions Cook the Beef & Onion Gravy: Heat oil in a pan and brown the beef pieces. Remove and set aside. In the same pan, cook onions until golden. Sprinkle with flour, stir well, then gradually add beef stock. Return beef to the pan, add Worcestershire sauce, and simmer gently for 1.5–2 hours until tender and thickened. Season to taste. Make the Boxty Pancakes: In a bowl, combine grated potato, mashed potato, flour, egg, and milk. Season with salt and pepper. Heat a little butter or oil in a frying pan and pour in ladlefuls of the batter to make thin pancakes. Cook for 2–3 minutes per side until golden. Assemble the Wraps: Place a spoonful of beef and onion gravy onto each pancake, roll tightly, and drizzle with extra gravy before serving. Why You’ll Love This Recipe Boxty Pancake Wraps with Beef & Onion Gravy are a true taste of Irish comfort food. The crispy-yet-soft potato pancakes perfectly complement the rich, slow-cooked beef filling. This dish is hearty, satisfying, and steeped in Irish tradition, making it a wonderful choice for family dinners or special occasions.

The post BOXTY PANCAKE WRAPS WITH BEEF AND ONION GRAVY appeared first on Irish Food Hub.

item.title: Grinder Pasta Salad
item.description:
All of the flavours of a grinder sandwich in a creamy pasta salad! A grinder sandwich is a sandwich filled with Italian cold cuts, such as pepperoni and salami, provolone cheese, tomato, onion, pepperoncini peppers, and lettuce tossed in a tasty dressing. This recipe is for a pasta salad with all of the same ingredients!...
